dt: {bc}to think of especially with regard to taking some action
{bc}to regard or treat in an attentive or kindly way

dt.t: I {wi}consider{/wi} it's best that he left when he did.

pt: {sc}consider{/sc} {sc}study{/sc} {sc}contemplate{/sc} {sc}weigh{/sc} mean to think about in order to arrive at a judgment or decision. {sc}consider{/sc} may suggest giving thought to in order to reach a suitable conclusion, opinion, or decision.
{sc}study{/sc} implies sustained purposeful concentration and attention to details and minutiae.
{sc}contemplate{/sc} stresses focusing one's thoughts on something but does not imply coming to a conclusion or decision.
{sc}weigh{/sc} implies attempting to reach the truth or arrive at a decision by balancing conflicting claims or evidence.

pt.t: {it}weigh{/it} the pros and cons of the case

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}considerer{/it}, from Latin {it}considerare{/it} to observe, think about, from {it}com-{/it} + {it}sider-, sidus{/it} heavenly body
shortdef: to think about carefully: such as
to think of especially with regard to taking some action

dt: used to say that one will gladly do something that he or she has been asked to do

dt.t: "Can you mail this letter for me?" "{it}Consider it done{/it}."

shortdef: —used to say that one will gladly do something that he or she has been asked to do

dt: {bc}to feel that one is fortunate (that something happened or didn't happen)

dt.t: He {it}considered himself fortunate{/it} to come out of the ordeal with just a broken leg.
{it}Consider yourself lucky{/it} that you survived the accident.

shortdef: to feel that one is fortunate (that something happened or didn't happen)
